economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as it became apparent that the rate lift-off would not occur in the october meeting, volatility in the global financial markets subsided.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:46:14,199 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the absence of a rate hike led to reduced volatility in global financial markets, suggesting a more accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee would also monitor the effectiveness of the relaxation of foreign exchange regulations to encourage capital outflows and consider implementing additional measures if necessary.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:46:17,594 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a relaxation of foreign exchange regulations to encourage capital outflows, which suggests a more accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: looking ahead, headline inflation was expected to gradually trend up toward target on account of domestic demand recovery and higher oil prices than in the previous year.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:46:20,443 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that headline inflation is expected to increase due to domestic demand recovery and higher oil prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: were geopolitical risks to materialize, risky assets in global financial markets might experience a sharp correction in prices.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates potential risks to global financial markets, which could lead to a downturn in economic growth, hinting at potential easing measures."
}

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: with regard to the exchange rates, the baht depreciated against the us dollar to a greater extent than other regional currencies due to the accelerated us dollar purchases by gold-trading companies when gold prices dropped and the repatriation of profits and dividends by foreign businesses in thailand.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a depreciation of the Thai Baht against the US dollar, which suggests potential inflationary pressures and may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: benefits from the export expansion were limited to some business sectors and still did not lend support to income and employment in the broader economy.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:46:30,894 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that the benefits of export expansion were limited and did not support income and employment in the broader economy, suggesting a need for monetary easing to boost economic growth."
}

influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee saw a need to closely monitor developments in trading partner economies together with the aforementioned risks and to assess their impacts on the thai economy that could occur through various macroeconomic linkages.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the committee's need to monitor developments in trading partner economies, but does not convey any specific stance or action, making it neutral."

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: a number of studies and experiences from other countries suggested that a prolonged period of low interest rates could lead to a build-up of financial imbalances in the economy.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:46:37,362 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that low interest rates could lead to financial imbalances, implying a potential need for tighter monetary policy to prevent these imbalances."
}

held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the direct impacts on the thai economy were limited since the value of exports to russia in 2021 was only 0.4 percent of total exports and russian tourists accounted for only 4 percent of total foreign tourists before the pandemic.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:46:40,756 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the limited direct impacts of the Russian economy on Thailand's economy, but does not provide any information that would suggest a need for monetary policy tightening or easing."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: meanwhile, real estate sector gained pace following a gradual recovery in domestic demand, with the general house price growth remaining close to the historical average rate.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:46:44,530 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports a stable growth in house prices, close to the historical average rate, indicating no significant inflationary or deflationary pressures."
}

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge
